For program1.py:
We are to compute, after each update, the total sum of awesomeness over all contiguous subarrays.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: The awesomeness of an array is the number of blocks of consecutive identical numbers.
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: For example, [1,1,1] has awesomeness 1, [1,2] has 2, [1,2,2] has 2, [1,2,2,3] has 3.
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: We note that the total awesomeness over all contiguous subarrays can be computed by considering the contributions of the boundaries between adjacent elements.
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: Specifically, consider two adjacent elements a[i] and a[i+1].
children.label: high_level_plan

children.text: They contribute to the awesomeness of a subarray [l, r] if and only if the subarray includes both i and i+1, and if a[i] ! = a[i+1].
children.label: code_analysis

children.text: In such a case, the boundary between i and i+1 will cause an extra block (so the awesomeness of the subarray is increased by 1 because of this boundary).
children.label: mental_execution

children.text: Moreover, note that the entire set of contiguous subarrays that include the segment [i, i+1] is: l in [1, i] and r in [i+1, n].
children.label: code_analysis

children.text:
There are i * (n - i) such subarrays. Therefore, the total awesomeness for the entire array is:
  base = n*(n+1)//2   (each single element is a subarray and has awesomeness 1, and then we add the boundaries)

But note: the awesomeness of a subarray [l, r] is 1 (for the first element) plus the number of indices j in [l, r-1] such that a[j] ! = a[j+1]. Therefore, the total sum is:
  total = (number of subarrays) + (for each adjacent pair (i, i+1) with a[i]!=a[i+1], the number of subarrays that include this boundary)

We note that the total awesomeness over all contiguous subarrays can be computed by considering the contributions of the boundaries between adjacent elements.
